template.name: Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent active

item.name: Host name of Zabbix agent running
Zabbix agent ping
item.description: The agent always returns 1 for this item. It could be used in combination with nodata() for availability check.

trigger.name: Zabbix agent is not available (or nodata for {$AGENT.NODATA_TIMEOUT})
trigger.description: For active agents, nodata() with agent.ping is used with {$AGENT.NODATA_TIMEOUT} as time threshold.

item.name: The High Load Process, more than {$PROCESS.ALARM}

trigger.name: The server {HOST.NAME} is not available!
trigger.description: You should checking the networks, networks interfaces and so on.

item.name: Number of mention about "Explain Plan" in logs

trigger.name: Teamcenter Alert: Business Logic Server has a problem DBMS performance
trigger.description: 1.Check your Teamcenter syslog and the seeking the strings that contained "Explain Plan" 2.Check your Database

trigger.name: Teamcenter Alert: Business Logic Server can not connect to DBMS
trigger.description:
Teamcenter business logic cannot connect to DBMS.
1.Check your Teamcenter syslog. 2.Check your Database and passwod life of infodba user.

item.name: Cache bytes
item.description: Cache Bytes is the sum of the Memory\\System Cache Resident Bytes, Memory\\System Driver Resident Bytes, Memory\\System Code Resident Bytes, and Memory\\Pool Paged Resident Bytes counters. This counter displays the last observed value only; it is not an average.

item.name: Free system page table entries
item.description: This indicates the number of page table entries not currently in use by the system. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak or you running out of memory.

trigger.name: Number of free system page table entries is too low (less {$MEM.PAGE_TABLE_CRIT.MIN} for 5m)
trigger.description: The Memory Free System Page Table Entries is less than {$MEM.PAGE_TABLE_CRIT.MIN} for 5 minutes. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak.

item.name: Memory page faults per second
item.description: Page Faults/sec is the average number of pages faulted per second. It is measured in number of pages faulted per second because only one page is faulted in each fault operation, hence this is also equal to the number of page fault operations. This counter includes both hard faults (those that require disk access) and soft faults (where the faulted page is found elsewhere in physical memory.) Most processors can handle large numbers of soft faults without significant consequence. However, hard faults, which require disk access, can cause significant delays.

item.name: Memory pages per second
item.description: This measures the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

trigger.name: The Memory Pages/sec is too high (over {$MEM.PAGE_SEC.CRIT.MAX} for 5m)
trigger.description: The Memory Pages/sec in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$MEM.PAGE_SEC.CRIT.MAX}. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

item.name: Memory pool non-paged
item.description: This measures the size, in bytes, of the non-paged pool. This is an area of system memory for objects that cannot be written to disk but instead must remain in physical memory as long as they are allocated. There is a possible memory leak if the value is greater than 175MB (or 100MB with the /3GB switch). A typical Event ID 2019 is recorded in the system event log.

item.name: CPU DPC time
item.description: Processor DPC time is the time that a single processor spent receiving and servicing deferred procedure calls (DPCs). DPCs are interrupts that run at a lower priority than standard interrupts. % DPC Time is a component of % Privileged Time because DPCs are executed in privileged mode. If a high % DPC Time is sustained, there may be a processor bottleneck or an application or hardware related issue that can significantly diminish overall system performance.

item.name: CPU interrupt time
item.description: The Processor Information\% Interrupt Time is the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interrupts during sample intervals. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, disk drivers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. This is an easy way to identify a potential hardware failure. This should never be higher than 20%.

trigger.name: CPU interrupt time is too high (over {$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger.description: "The CPU Interrupt Time in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}%." The Processor Information\% Interrupt Time is the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interrupts during sample intervals. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, disk drivers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. This is an easy way to identify a potential hardware failure. This should never be higher than 20%.

item.name: CPU privileged time
item.description: The Processor Information\% Privileged Time counter shows the percent of time that the processor is spent executing in Kernel (or Privileged) mode. Privileged mode includes services interrupts inside Interrupt Service Routines (ISRs), executing Deferred Procedure Calls (DPCs), Device Driver calls and other kernel-mode functions of the Windows® Operating System.

trigger.name: CPU privileged time is too high (over {$CPU.PRIV.CRIT.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger.description: The CPU privileged time in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$CPU.PRIV.CRIT.MAX}%.

dependency.name: CPU interrupt time is too high (over {$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}% for 5m)
dependency.expression: {Template SPLM Server General:perf_counter_en["\Processor Information(_total)\% Interrupt Time"].min(5m)}>{$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}

item.name: CPU user time
item.description: The Processor Information\% User Time counter shows the percent of time that the processor(s) is spent executing in User mode.

item.name: Context switches per second
item.description: Context Switches/sec is the combined rate at which all processors on the computer are switched from one thread to another. Context switches occur when a running thread voluntarily relinquishes the processor, is preempted by a higher priority ready thread, or switches between user-mode and privileged (kernel) mode to use an Executive or subsystem service. It is the sum of Thread\\Context Switches/sec for all threads running on all processors in the computer and is measured in numbers of switches. There are context switch counters on the System and Thread objects. This counter displays the difference between the values observed in the last two samples, divided by the duration of the sample interval.

item.name: CPU queue length
item.description: The Processor Queue Length shows the number of threads that are observed as delayed in the processor Ready Queue and are waiting to be executed.

trigger.name: CPU queue length is too high (over {$CPU.QUEUE.CRIT.MAX} for 5m)
trigger.description: The CPU Queue Length in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$CPU.QUEUE.CRIT.MAX}.

item.name: Number of threads
item.description: The number of threads used by all running processes.

item.name: Number of processes
item.description: The number of processes.

item.name: CPU utilization
item.description: CPU utilization in %

trigger.name: High CPU utilization (over {$CPU.UTIL.CRIT}% for 5m)
trigger.description: CPU utilization is too high. The system might be slow to respond.

item.name: System name
item.description: System host name.

trigger.name: System name has changed (new name: {ITEM.VALUE})
trigger.description: System name has changed. Ack to close.

item.name: System local time
item.description: System local time of the host.

trigger.name: System time is out of sync (diff with Zabbix server > {$SYSTEM.FUZZYTIME.MAX}s)
trigger.description: The host system time is different from the Zabbix server time.

item.name: Operating system architecture
item.description: Operating system architecture of the host.

item.name: Free swap space
item.description: The free space of swap volume/file in bytes.

item.name: Free swap space in %
item.description: The free space of swap volume/file in percent.

item.name: Total swap space
item.description: The total space of swap volume/file in bytes.

item.name: System description
item.description: System description of the host.

item.name: Uptime
item.description: System uptime in 'N days, hh:mm:ss' format.

trigger.name: Host has been restarted (uptime < 10m)
trigger.description: The device uptime is less than 10 minutes.

item.name: Current Size of Volume - VOL_SYS
item.description: tech.notes. zabbix agent should have access to monitoring folder!

trigger.name: The volume on {HOST.NAME} is full!
trigger.description: You should check your storage with Teamcenter volumes!

trigger.name: The volume on {HOST.NAME} is partially full!
trigger.description: You should check your storage with Teamcenter volumes!

item.name: Total memory
item.description: Total memory in Bytes

item.name: Used memory
item.description: Used memory in Bytes

item.name: Memory utilization
item.description: Memory utilization in %

trigger.name: High memory utilization ( >{$MEMORY.UTIL.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger.description: The system is running out of free memory.

item.name: Physical disks WMI get
item.description: Raw data of win32_perfformatteddata_perfdisk_physicaldisk.

discovery_rule.name: Windows services discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of Windows services of different types as defined in template's macros.

trigger_prototype.name: "{#SERVICE.NAME}" ({#SERVICE.DISPLAYNAME}) is not running (startup type {#SERVICE.STARTUPNAME})
trigger_prototype.description: The service has a state other than "Running" for the last three times.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk average queue size (avgqu-sz)
item_prototype.description: Current average disk queue, the number of requests outstanding on the disk at the time the performance data is collected.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read rate
item_prototype.description: Rate of read operations on the disk.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk utilization
item_prototype.description: This item is the percentage of elapsed time that the selected disk drive was busy servicing read or writes requests.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk is overloaded (util > {$VFS.DEV.UTIL.MAX.WARN}% for 15m)
trigger_prototype.description: The disk appears to be under heavy load

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write rate
item_prototype.description: Rate of write operations on the disk.

discovery_rule.name: Mounted filesystem discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of file systems of different types.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template SPLM Server General:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].last()}>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} and (({Template SPLM Server General:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},total].last()}-{Template SPLM Server General:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},used].last()})<5G or {Template SPLM Server General:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].timeleft(1h,,100)}<1d)
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is critically low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototype.description: Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}. Second condition should be one of the following: - The disk free space is less than 5G. - The disk will be full in less than 24 hours.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template SPLM Server General:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].last()}>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"} and (({Template SPLM Server General:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},total].last()}-{Template SPLM Server General:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},used].last()})<10G or {Template SPLM Server General:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].timeleft(1h,,100)}<1d)
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototype.description: Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}. Second condition should be one of the following: - The disk free space is less than 10G. - The disk will be full in less than 24 hours.

dependency.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is critically low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
dependency.expression: {Template SPLM Server General:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].last()}>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} and (({Template SPLM Server General:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},total].last()}-{Template SPLM Server General:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},used].last()})<5G or {Template SPLM Server General:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].timeleft(1h,,100)}<1d)

trigger.name: High swap space usage ( less than {$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN}% free)
trigger.description: This trigger is ignored, if there is no swap configured
